holidays.name: St. Nicholas Day
holidays.description: A celebration honoring St. Nicholas, the patron saint of children and gift-giving, often marked by leaving shoes out to be filled with treats and small gifts.
holidays.origin: Rooted in the traditions of St. Nicholas of Myra, a 4th-century Greek bishop known for his generosity, this day has inspired many modern gift-giving customs, including Santa Claus.
holidays.funFact: In some countries, children clean their shoes the night before, hoping St. Nicholas will leave candy or small toys inside!

holidays.name: National Pawnbrokers Day
holidays.description: A day to recognize the important role pawnbrokers play in communities by providing financial services and loans secured by personal property.
holidays.origin: Established by the National Pawnbrokers Association to celebrate their contributions and raise public awareness about the industry.
holidays.funFact: The pawnbroker symbol of three gold balls is said to originate from the Medici family crest in medieval Italy!

holidays.name: National Microwave Oven Day
holidays.description: A quirky day celebrating the invention and convenience of the microwave oven, which revolutionized cooking and reheating food.
holidays.origin: Commemorates the patent filing by Percy Spencer, who discovered microwave cooking in 1945, changing kitchen life forever.
holidays.funFact: Percy Spencer realized microwave cooking when a candy bar in his pocket melted while standing near a magnetron!

holidays.name: Repeat Day
holidays.description: A playful observance inviting people to do things twice to enjoy, reflect, or get a second chance at fun, conversation, or indulgence.
holidays.origin: Unofficial and modern, this day encourages embracing repetition for amusement or better outcomes in everyday life.
holidays.funFact: Some use Repeat Day as an excuse to have their second breakfast, twice as much coffee, or rewatch a favorite movie!
